nodes.bodyText:
@shoatman Technically, the second method was never required since acquireToken(params) can do all the same things.... That said....
I see this overload of signIn as having a different purpose from the _original signIn() and the newly added reauthorize() (soon to be renamed, signInAgain()

signIn without a prompt param will allow for SSO state pickup from the browser, if the user already has state
signIn with a prompt param allows the developer to tweak the prompt behavior for the first run, but just like the other signIn() method, also disalllows multiple invocations of signIn()
signInAgain() accepts no account at all, and can only be used once a user has already signed in -- it's purpose is only if you must reprompt the user for creds, as a banking app might upon relaunch
